paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
#Creating PySpark Context for usage in the project.
spark

%pyspark
#https://data.cityofnewyork.us/Public-Safety/Fire-Incident-Dispatch-Data/8m42-w767
#Loading Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data data from csv file to dataframe named df.
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data.csv", header='true')

#The data constitutes of 1,865,618 rows, which can be seen by uncommenting the below command.
#df.count() #1,865,618

#Remove rows containing nan value in any of the column from the dataset, so that it does not affect our further analysis.
df = df.dropna(how = 'any')

#After removing all rows containing nan values in any of the columns we are left with 1,523,310 rows, pn which we will perform our analysis.
#df.count() #1,523,310

#Creating a view named df_table to be used in sql query below which will contain data of year 2016 only.
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")
sqlDF = spark.sql("SELECT  * FROM df_table WHERE INCIDENT_DATETIME like '%2016%'").show()

#The number of rows that have 2016 data are 228,850.
#sqlDF.count() #228,850

#Write the sql output to Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv file
#sqlDF.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv")

%pyspark

#Loading Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016 data from csv file to dataframe named df. This file was created in the above code.
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv", header='true')

#This dataset has 228,850 rows on which we will perform our further analysis.
#df.count() #228,850

#Creating a view to be used in sql query
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")

#Extracting average response seconds grouped by zipcode and output is ordered by average response seconds
sqlDF_avg_rt = spark.sql("SELECT  ZIPCODE, AVG(INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY) as avg_response_time  FROM df_table GROUP BY ZIPCODE ORDER BY avg_response_time DESC")

#Displaying the above created dataframe
sqlDF_avg_rt.show()

#Write the sql output to Avg_RT_wrt_Zipcodes_2016.csv file
#sqlDF_avg_rt.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/Avg_RT_wrt_Zipcodes_2016.csv")

%pyspark
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv", header='true')
#df.count() #228,850

#Creating a view to be used in sql query
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")

#Extracting number of incidents grouped by zipcode and output is ordered by number of incidents
sqlDF_no_of_incidents = spark.sql("SELECT  ZIPCODE,  COUNT(*) as no_of_incidents FROM df_table GROUP BY ZIPCODE ORDER BY no_of_incidents DESC")

#Displaying the above created dataframe.
sqlDF_no_of_incidents.show()

#Write the sql output to no_of_incidents_wrt_zipcodes_2016.csv file
#sqlDF_no_of_incidents.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/no_of_incidents_wrt_zipcodes_2016.csv")

%pyspark
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv", header='true')

#Creating a view to be used in sql query
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")

#Extracting info of incidents of a particular Zipcode
#You can change the zipcode in the query below
sqlDF = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM df_table  WHERE ZIPCODE = 10003 ")

#Write the sql query output to an appropriate file
#sqlDF.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/10003_Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv")

%pyspark
##implementing KMeans on coordinates of a particular zipcode

from pyspark.ml.clustering import KMeans

# loads data into dataframe named df.
df = spark.read.format("libsvm").load("/shared/d/1003_coordinates_libsvmformat.txt")


# trains a k-means model, set setK to select number of clusters
kmeans = KMeans().setK(2).setSeed(1)
model = kmeans.fit(df)


# evaluate clustering by computing Within Set Sum of Squared Errors
wssse = model.computeCost(df)
print("Within Set Sum of Squared Errors = " + str(wssse))

# show the result.
centers = model.clusterCenters()

print("Cluster Centers: ")
for center in centers:
    print(center)

%pyspark

#Loading Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data data from csv file to dataframe named dfh1.
dfh1=spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data.csv", header = True)

#Remove rows containing nan value in any of the column from the dataset, so that it does not affect our further analysis.
dfh = dfh1.dropna(how = 'any')

#After removing all rows having nan values in any of the columns we are left with 1,523,310 rows to perform analysis on.
dfh.count()

%pyspark
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

#Creating a view named table1 to be used in sql query
dfh.createOrReplaceTempView("table1")
df1=spark.sql("select STARFIRE_INCIDENT_ID, INCIDENT_DATETIME, ZIPCODE, INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY from table1")

#Extracting Response time by zipcode and date time
df1.show()

%pyspark
from pyspark.sql.types import DateType

#extracting month and hour data from the INCIDENT_DATETIME column to perform further analysis based on month and season.
dfff1=df1.withColumn('month', concat(df1.INCIDENT_DATETIME.substr(0,2)))
dfff2=dfff1.withColumn('hour', concat(df1.INCIDENT_DATETIME.substr(12,2)))

#Displaying the dataframe values
dfff2.show()

%pyspark
#creating view named data1 to be used in the below written sql query.
dff3.createOrReplaceTempView("data1")

#Extracting average response time by each hour in a day on 12 hour clock.
dff4=spark.sql("select Hour, AVG(INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY) from data1 group by Hour")

#Writing the csv file for avg response time by zipcode and hour
#dff4.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("Hour_Response_time.csv")

#Display the values of dff4 dataframe.
dff4.show(50)

%pyspark
#Extracting the number of incidents occured for each hour on a 12 hpur clock
dff5=spark.sql("select hour, Count(*) as Number_of_Incidents from data1 group by hour")

#Writing the csv file for avg response time by zipcode and hour
#dff5.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("Hour_Number_Incidents.csv")
dff5.show()

%pyspark
#Extracting the number of incidents occured by season. The mapping for the seasons has been created in the above code block.
dff6=spark.sql("select season, Count(*) as Number_of_Incidents from data1 group by season")

#Writing the csv file for number of incidents by season
#dff6.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("Season_Number_Incidents.csv")
dff6.show()

%pyspark
#Extracting the average response time by each season.
dff7=spark.sql("select season, AVG(INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY) from data1 group by season")

#Writing the csv file for avg response time by season
#dff7.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("Season_Response _time.csv")
dff7.show()

%pyspark
#Extracting the average response time by each month.
dff8=spark.sql("select month, AVG(INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY) from data1 group by month")

#Writing the csv file for avg response time by month
#dff8.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("Month_Response _time.csv")
dff8.show()

%pyspark
#Extracting number of incidents occured by each month.
dff9=spark.sql("select month, count(*) as Number_of_Incidents from data1 group by month")

#Writing the csv file for number of incidents by each month
#dff9.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("Month_Zipcode_Incidents.csv")
dff9.show()

%pyspark

#Reading 2016 Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data into dataframe named df
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv", header='true')
#df.count() #228,850

#Creating a view named df_table to be used in sql query
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")

#Extracting number ofincidents grouped by INCIDENT_CLASSIFICATION and output is ordered by num_of_incidents seconds
sqlDF_avg_rt = spark.sql("SELECT  INCIDENT_CLASSIFICATION, COUNT(*) as num_of_incidents  FROM df_table GROUP BY INCIDENT_CLASSIFICATION ORDER BY num_of_incidents DESC")
sqlDF_avg_rt.show()

#Write the sql query output to an appropriate file
#sqlDF_avg_rt.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/number_of_incidents_per_type_2016.csv")

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
#Reading 2016 Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data into dataframe named df.
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv", header='true')

#The dataframe has 228,850 number of rows.
#df.count() #228,850

#Creating a view to be used in sql query
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")

#Extracting average response seconds grouped by INCIDENT_CLASSIFICATION and output is ordered by average response seconds
sqlDF_avg_rt = spark.sql("SELECT  INCIDENT_CLASSIFICATION, AVG(INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY) as avg_time_type  FROM df_table GROUP BY INCIDENT_CLASSIFICATION ORDER BY avg_time_type DESC")
sqlDF_avg_rt.show()

#Write the sql query output to an appropriate file
#sqlDF_avg_rt.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/average_responce_per_type_2016.csv")

%pyspark
#Reading 2016 Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data into dataframe named df.
df = spark.read.csv("/shared/d/Fire_Incident_Dispatch_Data_2016.csv", header='true')

#The dataframe has 228,850 number of rows.
#df.count() #228,850

#Creating a view named df_table to be used in sql query
df.createOrReplaceTempView("df_table")

#Extracting frequency of incidents grouped by INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY  and output is ordered by num_of_incidents_same_time 
sqlDF_avg_rt = spark.sql("SELECT CAST( INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY AS int) as INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS , COUNT(*) as num_of_incidents_same_time  FROM df_table GROUP BY INCIDENT_RESPONSE_SECONDS_QY ORDER BY num_of_incidents_same_time DESC ")
sqlDF_avg_rt.show()

#Write the sql query output to an appropriate file
#sqlDF_avg_rt.coalesce(1).write.option("header", "true").csv("/shared/d/project/frequency_of_responce_time_2016.csv")
%pyspark
